topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Install the Database Service

ul.li: The HDP Installer 2.0, also known as HDPI, must already be installed.

section.title: Configure Availability Zones
section.p: To configure the Database Service in a highly available manner, it is necessary to create separate availability zones. Best practice is to create three availability zones. All hosts should be associated with one of these availability zones, or the Database Service will not be able to provision a database instance on that host. This may cause the Database Service may run out of capacity even though there are unassociated hosts that still have room.
The following steps show how to create three availability zones and assign a compute host to the zone.

ol.li:
Download an RC file for the admin user and project.
Log in to Horizon using the admin account.
Download the OpenStack RC file.
Use scp to copy the RC file over to the Deployer.
SSH to the Deployer and source the RC file. You will need to provide the same admin password that you used to log in to Horizon.
source admin-openrc.sh

Execute the following commands to create three availability zones named: "AZ-1", "AZ-2" and "AZ-3".openstack aggregate create --zone AZ-1 aggregate-AZ-1 openstack aggregate create --zone AZ-2 aggregate-AZ-2 openstack aggregate create --zone AZ-3 aggregate-AZ-3
Validate that the availability zones were correctly created by issuing the following command.openstack aggregate list

The following commands will add a host to your newly created aggregate. Execute this command once for every host that you wish to associate with an aggregate.openstack aggregate add host <aggregate name or id> <host>
The following command can be used to list all availability zones and the hosts associated with each one.openstack availability zone list

section.title: Set Quotas
section.p: The project tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused resources for the service to use. To check existing quota availability, log in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

In addition to the quotas mentioned above, for every database instance that is created by a user, the necessary resources to create that instance will be deducted from the admin project quota. The user's database service quota will also be affected.

ol.li: List the available database versions to install: openstack hdpi list --os-cloud mycloud | grep database The output should look similar to:database | wscatalog.#### | 2.0.0.0 | available
Select the database version to install and view the details of the package:openstack hdpi show wscatalog.#### --os-cloud mycloud

Install the database service.openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi database install --package wscatalog.#### The output will appear similar to: $ os hdpi database install --package wscatalog.#### Database is now downloading ... ...Downloading may take a significant amount of time; depending on network traffic, it could take 20-90 minutes.Database is (downloaded) Database is already (available) Database is already configured Launching stack... Stack trove creating Completed installing database $

section.sectiondiv:
Configure HAProxyThe following steps will configure HAProxy to receive and forward HTTP requests to the VM that hosts the REST API endpoint for the Database Service.
Identify all the API server IPs on the SVC network. You should have as many API servers (and IPs) as you have Availability Zones in your HPE Helion OpenStack installation.
openstack server list | awk '/trove[0-9]*_api/{ print $4,"\t", substr($8,5) }'
Identify the Virtual IP used to load balance the HPE Helion OpenStack services:openstack endpoint show database -c publicurl --format value
Update configuration on each of the HPE Helion OpenStack controller nodes. The last line in each codeblock should be repeated once for each API server identified in step 1. The ssl cert information in the bind statement only applies if SSL has been enabled for public endpoints. If SSL has not been enabled, omit this section of the statement. To locate the filepath, navigate to ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/tls-frontend/defaults/main.yml and find the value of the frontend_server_cert_directory parameter. To find the file name, open the /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml file and find the value for the cert-file parameter.
Connect to the controller node and add the following lines to the /etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg file. listen trove_api bind <virtual IP from step 2>:8779 ssl crt <path to certificate file/certFileName> option httpchk GET / server trove-trove<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5
Connect to the controller node and add the following lines to the ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/haproxy/templates/haproxy.cfg file. This will ensure your settings persist between reboots.listen trove_api bind <virtual IP from step 2>:8779 ssl crt <path to certificate file/certFileName> option httpchk GET / server trove-trove<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5
Add the following command to the /etc/iptables/rules.v4 file. This will ensure that this rule persists. -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Run the following command:sudo iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Reload the haproxy service configuration.sudo service haproxy reload
The installation is complete. Return to the Horizon dashboard (you may log out and log in with a non-Admin account if desired), and click the Database panel under the current Project to begin using the Database Service.
